Text:
Im not a big planner to begin with probably due to my lack of enjoyment for more mainstream planners like Google calendar and traditional paper planners Google while claiming to be userfriendly had too many tools and GUIs to navigate through which felt overwhelming to me while still lacking the flexibility I desired Paper planners I encountered in the store didnt do the job either because they were not formatted exactly how I wanted and of course a regular old notebook didnt provide the online accessibility I wanted
Notion is everything you wanted in a planner and truly helped bring the planning side of me back to reality It provided helpful templates I could use to give an overall format for what I wanted to write checklists boxes etc which were incredibly customizable The tool is simple yet powerful without any unnecessary visual effects or special features you are forced to learn I love that Notion can be accessed on any device via the website or app and my plans look the exact same in any format without shifting its orientation or completely uphauling the website layout I would recommend this to anyone
Summary: User finds Notion helpful for organizing their daily tasks and planning their week, as it provides templates and customizable tools for organizing their tasks. They appreciate the flexibility and ease of use, and find it helpful for their daily tasks.

Text:
Miro helps solve group collaboration on final presentations I had been using InDesign before but couldnt get everyones eyes on my document quickly The ability to brainstorm and share notes when conducting research has also been an important part for my team with some members having fully remote positions
The thing I find most helpful with Miro is the collaboration Instead of sharing versions of documents around or trying to record physical notes in a way for my whole team to see we all have the most current online version that is easy to work with and create beautiful designs
There are few downsides to using Miro sometimes others feel intimidated by using it but usually that changes quick I use Miro to create presentations and designs which works well and creates highresolution documents and while it offers more flexibility in design than PowerPoint I have to be creative to get the designs I want
Summary: Users appreciate Miro's ability to facilitate remote collaboration in a hybrid work environment, especially during the pandemic. They find it valuable for documenting workshops, capturing ideas, and brainstorming. However, they mention minor issues with table functionality and shape modification for wireframing.

Text:
I can analyse data in visual form really quickly on Miro  it really helps connect the dots when you can see all of the information in one space it is also really helpful as a collaborative tool  i no longer have to be the single scribe everyone can contribute actively during brainstorming and it really helps with getting open feedback from stakeholders which is not often easy to do verbally i dont think i could be without miro especially in a remote working environment
Working fully remotely Miro is my most frequently used software because there is no other tool that lets me collaborate ideate and present information across screens more easily than Miro I cant say that i even miss physical brainstorming boards because i no longer have to transfer handwritten notes to a digital format  it saves so much time and nothing goes missing its really easy to track information and review past discussions because everything is captured digitally all of the tools and templates are very handy i dont have to think to much about how to structure information  its plug and play and theres so much you can do the interface is very intuitive
Miro on ipad pro could be improved to leverage the capabilities of tablets i use miro exclusively on my computer and hardly ever on the ipad because it is very buggy and takes too long to do what i would normally do on a computer writing is fine but its not enough for me to also use miro on my tablet  its a shame but i guess Freeform is a good simple and free alternative it would also be great if Miro could be used in offline mode with an option to sync once online
Summary: User appreciates Figma's ease of use and helpful templates but faces challenges with navigation, specifically zooming in and out. They need a way to visualize processes, organize wireframes for presentations, and document software.

Text:
Miro is an excellent and exceptional tool for myself and also my customers 
Its an amazing tool for documentation and visual thinking 
Allows teams from different locations to interact and share ideas
Miro usability and flexibility is the reason why we decided to use it 
It is simple and easy to adapt the application 
It supports powerful tools i love most such as sticky notes mapping brainstorming polls etc 
One can comfortably use it from any device as it supports mobile version desktop version and browser version 
Miro is not expensive compared to other alternatives out there
One of the challenges is that sometimes navigation isnt good with zooming in and out and also browsing is a little bit cumbersome when there is too much content on the same board
Summary: Users appreciate Miro for its collaborative planning and discovery features, making complex discussions simple and accessible for teams in various fields. However, they find connecting shapes to be buggy and wish for better integration with PowerPoint or other export solutions.

Text:
Lack of visual communication Traditional communication methods like emails or chats can sometimes make it difficult to convey complex ideas or visualize a concept FigJam solves this problem by providing an easytouse whiteboarding tool that allows teams to quickly create visual representations of their ideas and share them with others
FigJam is a collaborative online whiteboarding tool created by Figma that allows teams to work together in realtime to brainstorm plan and visualize ideas One of the best things about FigJam is its ease of use and intuitive interface which makes it simple for even nondesigners to quickly create diagrams flowcharts wireframes and other types of visual content
sometimes UI could be complicated if youre a user that are not familiar with the FIGMA infinite canvas system that you can scroll a lot and not find the end Aside from that is great
Summary: Users appreciate Miro for its collaboration features, enabling teams to work together on presentations and designs more efficiently than with InDesign or PowerPoint. Miro is particularly helpful for remote team members, though some users may initially feel intimidated. While it offers more design flexibility, users may need to be creative to achieve desired results.

Text:
How to turn an almost perfect UIUX to perfect
Using  as a perfect example created by cnnr_cllhn 
cnnr_cllhn LoseTheVery is a fantastic tool that finds a more concise adjective without using very Example very rich  affluent
The core idea is simple and the UI was chosen to reflect that Its straight to the point just like the Google Search homepage So whats the problem 
cnnr_cllhn  There are 3 main flaws
1 Site feels messy
2 Design lacks consistency
3 Elements feel a little too cramped
Well approach it via negativa style by removing stuff rather than adding
 Lets work on that that using figma
cnnr_cllhn figma 1 Decluttering 
The most important step would be to remove the clutter  the annoying newsletter popup the newsletter section and the newsletter banner Well get back to it later
This has already made a difference The interface looks significantly cleaner 
cnnr_cllhn figma 2 Let the design breathe 
Lets add more whitespace  the more the better This will achieve a better visual separation
Now the very  x  y line instantly grabs our attention 
cnnr_cllhn figma 3 Making buttons prettier 
Buttons look chaotic here randomly spaced different padding etc
Lets increase the font size adjust the padding and replace the word random with a dice icon Well also invert the third button
The buttons now look modern and consistent

Text:
I use it for several things private documents to guide my thinking and notes collaborative whiteboards sharing diagrams with colleagues and documentation
As far as Im aware Miro is unique in its ability to enable a user to rapidly build diagrams in realtime while other users observe or contribute simultaneously I can create flow charts and diagrams so quickly And its easy to make the results look great
The tables feature is lackluster but its still an experiment Other than that the licensing model has been slightly annoying to deal with If I want a colleague to contribute to a board they need a full license even if they use it for 30 minutes and never use it again This arrangement doesnt feel optimal from a fairness and value pointofview but I still find the tool to be worth the money
Summary: The user finds Figma helpful for designing and creating diagrams, making requirements easily understandable for developers and testers. However, they face an issue with different UI versions getting minimized and reflecting other versions when maximized.

Text:
Prototyping Allows me to visualize how the final product can look like and easily share my vision with others Ease of use makes it easy for someone without a design background to understand
I really like how Figma is easy to use Helpful tutorials for finding and downloading plugins to achieve everything you need Easy to collaborate on this tool
No built in flattening tool when exporting file as pdf If there is a built in flattening tool it would be really helpful For now you would need to export each page as png and then reinsert to get around the lack of flattening tool
Summary: Users appreciate Miro for its ability to streamline creative collaboration and provide a single platform for idea sharing and project management. They enjoy the accessibility and endless possibilities for creativity. However, they experience performance issues when boards have too much content, causing slow editing and freezing. Improving performance with heavy boards is a suggested improvement.

Text:
This is my 1 choice of tool when collaborating with clients My team uses Miro to document a strategy or wireframe and collect client feedback in realtime it helps ensure the client that we are listening to their wants and needs Instead of using a static PPT where we are just jotting down the notes clients can see the work in action In addition we use the Miro board to document processes and attach key artifacts and URLS This process documentation is exhaustive but Miro allows users to zoom in and out from a micromacro view to learn about the process which is great for leadership to see and great for onboarding It especially works for a global remote company where we can all jump in to review no matter the time zone If you are in the same time zone it works great to get everyone in the room and use as a collaboration tool For example Im located in California and my client is located in the UK We use miro to make updates on our timezone and get very detailed in specific areas of question It allows for transparency review and collaboration
In general I like the whiteboarding and mapping capabilities that allow for deep thought process documentation and pure collaboration with teams It allows me to jot my rough thoughts on paper where I then can find patterns and create a more solid process Miro is the perfect think tank environment that you use from start ideation to a finish a solid concept Its also great for inviting colleagues for feedback or collaboration Anyone can use it with a free license
Miroboards have a size capacity where if you add too many screenshots it starts to slow down It can also get extremely messy and often confusing for a new user coming in and unsure where to start Sometimes if you start your miroboard too big the details of things like adding arrow connectors can be really tiny Causing me to selecting all and sizing down my space so you can see these details I sometimes run into issues with font formatting if I copied and pasted a highlighted text in bold and then I drag in the text widget it will copy what Ive used when that is not my intention Its really just the small details that I wish were fixed that could make my experience more easier
Summary: The user appreciates Figma's ease in creating whiteboards for moodboards and presentations but finds it challenging to locate options for adding links or importing images and creating clipping masks.

They identified three main flaws: messiness, inconsistency in design, and cramped elements. Using Figma, they suggested decluttering by removing unnecessary newsletter elements, adding more whitespace for better visual separation, improving button design for consistency, and simplifying typography by using only two typefaces.

Text:
I really enjoy using notion for note taking and syncing between devices works flawlessly Also lots of options to structure your notes embed different components create small databases for recipies and such etc
There are a few flaws though there is no offline mode the AI features that I dont use cannot be deactivated is is not as fast as a native app like apple notessimplenoteetc there is no real pensupport for drawing and sketching the app logs me out frequently and that feeling of having too many eggs in one basket
One improvement that would be great on iOS when I share a youtube video to a notion database via share sheet the URL is the title It would be great if the title was the video title and the URL was an embedded video in the content Adding Tags when sharing would also be helpful
Summary: User enjoys using Notion for note-taking and syncing between devices, but has issues with the lack of offline mode, AI features not being deactivated, and the app logging them out frequently. It has a larger workspace than what I typically use in Microsoft Powerpoint Allows for a much larger workspace to create in and can shift easily between different sections

Text:
People often ask me for good examples of executive communication lets talk about joshm the CEO of browsercompany 
And the intelligent and underrated use of YouTube for a business 
Its particularity He chose as a social network to express himself YouTube Uncommon
Concretely browsercompany has a channel with 20k subscribers and 2 types of videos
 the culture and vision of the company
 tutorials and advice for its users
 
We will mainly focus on the first category the one in which joshm is personally involved
In terms of form these videos are YouTubefriendly that is to say
 exclusive no balanced body videos on all channels
 1020 minutes
 with a chapter
There are 2 formats that I particularly like
1 its QA in early 2023 to report and answer for example the question of its business model with embedded graphs and dataviz 72k views 3rd channel video
 
What is interesting is that this video starts from a tweet that he posted in early December just before the 2nd meeting of the browsercompany board with the desire to be transparent and accountable to his users build in public

And hey presto 2 weeks later he answers it in this famous video

2 A video where he films himself in a photo booth from his Mac desktop which allows him to browse his Finder and show content images sounds videos etc by unfolding his story Funny with a touch of brothelartisan
 
This format was called videofile_ and allows browsercompany to tell its new features and the philosophy behind each time being embodied by an employee not just the CEO And given the engagement rates thats interesting

Text:
Were working on a larger Component library that includes nonpublished components components with the prefix _ or  as base components in order to simplify large complex components We intended  in some specific cases  to offer regular components as templates that a designer would then have to detach and work with a bunch of base components to build the desired design
What we have come to realize with this approach however is that these nonpublished components dont receive updates from the library when they are updated in the main library
Is this intended behaviour
We basically have the option to simply publish these base components as regular components but that of course would mean cluttering up the assets overview with a bunch of modular components
hi Raphael our team is also facing the same issue for a while Have you or your team figured out the workaround for this issue I wish Figma can solve this issue fundamentally Josh thank you

Text:
Miro gives us the ability to collaborate teach learn share and be in one place no matter where in the world we live It is extremely valuable in these times where costs are of the utmost concern and we try to continue our ability to get together as teams to accomplish our goals
I like the ability to customize and build the collaboration space that is most effective I look through the templates and Miroverse to begin as inspiration and then build to support the goals of the session
The structure for us to do multiple sessions within our company is due to the terms of our contract It becomes a little prohibitive based on the number of people and days we need to be most effective
Summary: User appreciates the infinite canvas, voting, stickers, and rich diagramming tools in Figma, as well as multiple app integration, allowing them to use it as their primary productivity tool. They also appreciate the lack of a private space in the enterprise version, which only allows them to keep documents for themselves.

Text:
Miro is helping us to work remotely by helping us to collaborate more efficiently It is easier to gather feedback in user research using Miro We are using Miro to conduct our Sprint Retrospectives which provides many inbuilt templates After any workshop or interview the outputs are summarised in Miro and it is reviewed within team virtually without having to schedule any meeting
It helps teams to collaborate efficiently and exchange ideas It acts as a virtual whiteboard and allows teams in different parts of the globe to interact and exchange ideas
Lots of features and difficult to lock frames
Summary: Users appreciate Figma's ease of use and aesthetics but face challenges in distributing information effectively when working remotely with cross-functional teams. They also experience occasional sluggishness and lag when loading boards and moving flows.

Text:
People often ask me for good examples of executive communication lets talk about joshm the CEO of browsercompany 
And the intelligent and underrated use of YouTube for a business 
Its particularity He chose as a social network to express himself YouTube Uncommon
Concretely browsercompany has a channel with 20k subscribers and 2 types of videos
 the culture and vision of the company
 tutorials and advice for its users
 
We will mainly focus on the first category the one in which joshm is personally involved
In terms of form these videos are YouTubefriendly that is to say
 exclusive no balanced body videos on all channels
 1020 minutes
 with a chapter
There are 2 formats that I particularly like
1 its QA in early 2023 to report and answer for example the question of its business model with embedded graphs and dataviz 72k views 3rd channel video
 
What is interesting is that this video starts from a tweet that he posted in early December just before the 2nd meeting of the browsercompany board with the desire to be transparent and accountable to his users build in public

And hey presto 2 weeks later he answers it in this famous video

2 A video where he films himself in a photo booth from his Mac desktop which allows him to browse his Finder and show content images sounds videos etc by unfolding his story Funny with a touch of brothelartisan
 
This format was called videofile_ and allows browsercompany to tell its new features and the philosophy behind each time being embodied by an employee not just the CEO And given the engagement rates thats interesting 
2 other videos that were a hit  a metavideo where the CEO watches and reacts to a review of his browser by one of the biggest tech influencers MKBHD Its THE most popular video with 343K views Skilled at surfing on his visibility

 a vlog with members of the browsercompany board who clearly plays the behindthescenes strategicmeetingsthatnotsoseetosee card the kind of content that always works 
In short obviously the formats make sense with browsercompanys activity  developing a web browser  but in any case its a breath of fresh air about what should be the communication of a manager who reports on his vision and the progress of his company

Text:
Announcements in the world of AI today
Anthropic expands Claudes context window to 100000
Stability AIs new texttoanimation tool
Meta introduces the AI sandbox
Airtable unveils Airtable AI
Heres the rundown on everything you need to know
1 Anthropic revolutionizes Claude AI
Anthropic is boosting Claude their AI model by expanding its context window from a mere 9000 tokens to a whopping 100000 tokens
Claude can now analyze and interpret not just a few pages but hundreds 
The model could digest and analyze the entire text of The Great Gatsby in less than a minute 
This puts OpenAIs GPT4 and its 32k context window currently in beta in the dust 
2 Stability AIs texttoanimation tool
Stability AI just unveiled a powerful texttoanimation tool called Stable Animation SDK
Users can generate animations from text images or video combined with text 
3 Meta unveils generative AI for advertisers
Meta just introduced the AI Sandbox a playground for advertisers to try new generative AIpowered ad tools

Text:
_Dave__White_ and I are excited to open source our power tool for interacting w LLMs Flux
Flux allows you to generate multiple completions per prompt in a tree structure and explore the best ones in parallel
Try it out at  
Fluxs tree structure lets you
 Get a wider variety of creative responses
 Test out different prompts with the same shared context
 Use inconsistencies to identify where the model is uncertain 
Flux also
 Has a robust set of keyboard shortcuts
 Allows setting the system message and editing GPT messages
 Autosaves to local storage
 Uses the OpenAI API directly
 Is open source and MIT licensed
Bug reports amp PRs welcome on Github 
Flux has been a major boost to our workflows and we hope it can do the same for you
Thank you to repligate for inspiring us with Loom ctjlewis for maintaining the awesome openaistreams library Flux is built on and of course _yangyou for her brilliant designs and feedback
PS This is only a bare bones version of what we imagine Flux could become
If youre interested in working with us on Flux or _Dave__White_s new game  wed love to talk w you
Reach out via DM or at t11s EMAIL_ADDRESS 
We have been working on an LLM collaboration tool using ceramicnetworks ComposeDB and of course flux 
Think of figma for prompt design

Text:
I use Miro mainly for workshoppign internally or with clients I use the consulting plan to balance cost with flexibility and confidentiality I often use miro even during face to face workshops to capture the productions in real time
Overall an excellent choice for facilitating collaboration during workshops and teambased activities Its realtime collaboration capabilities enable users to work together seamlessly whether inperson or remote fostering a more interactive and productive workshop experience The wide range of tools and templates such as mind maps and Kanban boards caters to various use cases making it easy to adapt the platform for different activities Furthermore Miros integration with rich media such as videos and PDF ensures effortless sharing and access to work across platforms streamlining team collaboration
Performance issues can arise when working with large boards or a high number of simultaneous users which may result in lag or slow loading times Additionally the platforms customization options can sometimes feel restrictive especially when users require more flexibility in tailoring Miro to their specific needs
Summary: The user appreciates Figma's flexibility and ease of use for conveying ideas and concepts, as it caters to visual learners. However, they experience long loading times when opening the app, which can be inconvenient during short meetings.

Text:
I first came across it during an online course and fell in love with it So I adopted it for my teams working from home Now we are pretty much back in the office but its still my go to We all sit around a massive table to collab and ideate and its all captured in real time on the board I find it really aesthetically pleasing which helps and whatever I need there is a template for it or something that can be tweaked
The infinity of the boards is excellent  the templates tools colours simplicity of navigation and its super intuitive so you dont have to learn loads of new stuff to use it I love you can bring people to you  I love the tutorials I love Miroverses
When I have invited people to join my team they inevitably love it and go off to create their own which results in one of my boards being disabled to its a bit of a faff to sling them out of my team copy the content to a new board and then get my board back 
Also I really struggle with the  zoom My boards have been built at 1 so when I copy and paste something in its always so tiny that I have to locate a spec and zoom in to highlight this to drag and enlarge Its a massive pain I dont know how to fix this now
Summary: The user finds the Enterprise team management feature in Miro very helpful for understanding the challenges and benefits of Continuous Improvement Initiatives, such as real-time collaboration and avoiding business travel for workshops and meetings. They also mention that it could be more intuitive for early adopters.

Text:
Documenting information in diagramsmaps helps the team visualize complex information architecture and align on foundations 
Sketching ideas in low fidelity increases our time to value at early design stages by allowing us to validate concepts before investing in highfidelity visualizations Having a space to collaborate on these lowfidelity designs makes the validation process more efficient and consolidates the thinking 
Using FigJam to share information with less designsavvy coworkers offers a friendly way to collect and organize inspiration or audits
FigJam makes it easy for me to sketch ideas map information in diagrams and collaborate with others Theres just enough design functionality to bring concepts to life without getting lost in the details Additional tools make workshops or brainstorming sessions fun and easy for my nondesigner colleagues to pick up I love having access to communitymade templates and graphics for inspiration
I wish participants could be invited to edit files without having a licensed seat I have run interactive workshops with participants who do not regularly use the tool and getting folks proper access in these cases is a bit tricky In cases where I have colleagues who need temporary access to files I use open sessions but need to reopen them each time the colleague requires edit access
Summary: Users appreciate Miro as a common platform for collaboration and visualization, which helps in daily presentations and organizing Agile events. However, they suggest improving the pen functionality for a smoother writing experience and propose the addition of a touchpad for more natural drawing

Summary: Flux is an open-source power tool for interacting with LLMs, allowing users to generate multiple completions per prompt in a tree structure and explore the best ones in parallel. It offers a variety of creative responses, tests different prompts with shared context, and identifies model uncertainties. Flux also features keyboard shortcuts, system message editing, autosaving, and direct use of the OpenAI API. The creators are open to collaboration and are working on an LLM collaboration tool using Ceramic Network's ComposeDB and Flux, similar to Figma for prompt design.
